title: Why Middle East stability revolves around Israel
summary: Le Monde looks back at the history of Israel's relations with its Arab neighbors and the intractable and complicated quest for peace in the Middle East, made of alliances and betrayals.

title: From clubs to couches: Why the 'indoor generation' prefers a night in
summary: Nightlife venues are running on empty, and the trend of staying home is flourishing on social media. Inflation, feelings of insecurity and the pandemic are just some of the reasons why young people are partying in a different way.

title: The Depardieu case blurs all standards, including those of Emmanuel Macron
summary: The president was keen to defend the actor, who is under investigation for rape and sexual assault, going so far as to disown his culture minister and give credence to 'fake news.' Since then, the controversy has dragged Macron and a segment of the French film industry into its radioactive wake.

title: The memory of a massacre ordered by Stalin in Russia exists on borrowed time
summary: A parliamentary commission has been tasked with reassessing Russia's official position on the massacre of 4,400 Polish officers perpetrated on in the forest of Katyn.

title: Islamic State group claims responsibility for Iran suicide bombings killing at least 84 people
summary: The IS group has claimed responsibility for twin bombings at a memorial ceremony in Iran for slain Revolutionary Guards general Qasem Soleimani that killed at least 84 people and wounded another 284.

title: A drink with Isabella Rossellini: 'As a Neapolitan poet friend of mine used to say, I'm a hoper, not a believer'
summary: At the age of 71, this cinema and beauty icon is starring in 'La Chimera'. Le Monde met her for a drink in a hotel just a stone's throw from the Louvre.

title: US says carried out Iraq strike, killed pro-Iran commander
summary: The strike comes amid heightened regional tensions linked to the war between US ally Israel and Iran-backed Hamas militants in the Gaza Strip.

title: Northern France has flooded once again: 'You can't do anything about water'
summary: In Arques, near Saint-Omer, homes already impacted by flooding in November are inundated again.

title: Tensions erupt in French film star Delon's family
summary: A row between Alain Delon and his son Anthony over comments in an interview has prompted the actor to seek to file a legal complaint against his son.

title: Cheddar: The inimitable taste of microbial interactions
summary: A dash of 'Streptococcus thermophilus' and a pinch of 'L. lactis' and 'L. cremoris': The different strains and the complexity of their interactions that are behind the British cheese's flavor have just been discovered.

title: UK's Sunak eyes 'second half' of 2024 for election
summary: The British Conservative party, which has had five leaders and prime ministers in 14 years, is widely expected to lose the election.

title: 'Multiple gunshot victims' in Iowa school shooting says sheriff
summary: Multiple people were shot inside a small-town Iowa high school as students prepared to start their first day of classes after their annual winter break.

title: Jeffrey Epstein documents: US judge begins to unseal court records
summary: Notably included in the documents, which include almost 1,000 pages of depositions and statements, were former US presidents Bill Clinton and Donald Trump, who have not been accused of any wrongdoing in the case.

title: Assassination of a Hamas leader in Beirut sparks fears of regional conflict
summary: A drone strike attributed to Israel targeted the deputy chairman of Hamas' political bureau, Saleh al-Arouri. He had been living in exile in a Hezbollah stronghold within Beirut.

title: Iran hit by deadliest attack since 1979
summary: At least 84 people were killed, according to authorities, when two bombs exploded in a crowd in Kerman commemorating the death of Revolutionary Guards Commander Qasem Soleimani.

title: India inaugurates Narendra Modi selfie booths ahead of general elections
summary: In railway stations, waiting passengers will soon be able to take a photo of themselves with a life-size reproduction of the prime minister, in yet another example of an excessive cult of personality.

title: As of today, Britain's top CEOs have earned a full year of an average worker's salary
summary: With £3.81 million of median earnings, this year the UK's top CEOs have earned the median annual salary  – £34,963 – in just two and a half days.

title: Giorgia Meloni suspends Italian MP who took gun to NYE party
summary: A guest was shot in the thigh, although not seriously injured. Emanuele Pozzolo, a lawmaker for Meloni's far-right Brothers of Italy party, has admitted to owning the mini revolver but says he did not fire it.

title: New York City suing charter bus companies for transporting migrants from Texas
summary: Approximately 33,000 migrants have been transported by bus from Texas to New York City since April 2022.

title: Germany hit by massive flooding
summary: Heavy rainfall has caused many rivers to overflow in large parts of the country, particularly in the west. The regions are not equally prepared to handle such events.

title: The far-right Reform UK party hopes to capitalize on the Conservatives' weakness
summary: Co-founded by Nigel Farage, the political group has announced that it will field candidates for the parliamentary elections 'in every constituency' in the country. It is campaigning against 'mass migration,' for which the Tories are allegedly responsible.

title: One student dead, four other people injured in Iowa school shooting
summary: The shooting happened Thursday morning in Perry, about 55 kilometers from the state capital, Des Moines.

title: Canada's carbon tax under threat from all sides
summary: Residents of the province of Saskatchewan will now be exempt from the federal tax. This latest development comes after Justin Trudeau himself opened a loophole in the emissions reduction system.

title: Iceland's population soon to hit the 400,000 mark
summary: Since 2008, the island's population has increased by over 20%. The upsurge in tourism has been driven by its foreign workforce.

title: Olympics: What legacy for Paris 2024?
summary: The organizing committee hopes the Games will leave behind something other than massive public spending.

title: Israel's defense minister unveils plan for post-war Gaza
summary: Yoav Gallant says Israel reserves the right to operate inside the territory, drawing condemnation from Arab states and its ally, the United States.

title: Oscar Pistorius, jailed for killing girlfriend, to be released
summary: The former Paralymic champion was sentenced to 13 years in prison after he shot dead Reeva Steenkamp in 2013.

title: What legacy for Paris 2024? The metamorphosis of Barcelona during the 1992 Olympics
summary: New roads, cultural and sporting venues, the creation of entire neighborhoods and the opening up of the waterfront: The Olympic Games, still widely celebrated today, shaped the Catalan capital of today.

title: 'The French immigration system is a prisoner of the past'
summary: Economist El Mouhoub Mouhoud says France 'has not been able to make the transition to an open and positive immigration policy' – an essential step for meeting the challenges of reindustrialization and artificial intelligence.

title: What legacy for Paris 2024? The exemplary conversion of the London 2012 Olympic Park
summary: Almost 12 years after the Olympic Games in the British capital, sports facilities are still in use, housing has been built and cultural and university venues are being created. But a lot of infrastructure is far from finished.

title: Israel's Golani Brigade on the front line in the Gaza Strip
summary: One of the country's oldest military units paid a heavy toll in the October 7 attack, which killed more than 70 of its members. Since then, its soldiers have been on the front line of the campaign against Hamas.

title: Mary Poppins star Glynis Johns dies aged 100
summary: The Tony Award-winning actress played Winifred Banks opposite Julie Andrews and was famed for the Stephen Sondheim hit 'Send in the Clowns,' which was written for her.

title: Terrorism prevention: The impossibility of zero risk
summary: After this autumn's knife attacks in Arras and Paris, ineffective demagogic proposals to prevent further terrorist attacks have flourished. Yet long-term reintegration programs, combined with judicial and administrative follow-up, have proved their worth.

title: The French-Japanese designer putting a fashionable twist on the culinary arts
summary: Marie Méon, founder of the creative agency Manger Manger, creates refined Japanese-style dinners and buffets for fashion houses, staged like works of art.

title: France bids farewell to former EU chief Delors
summary: The former president of the European Commission and French finance minister was honored with a state funeral in Paris on Friday, January 5.

title: 'Rue David Bowie': Paris to name street after rock icon
summary: The street on the French capital's Left Bank will honor the British singer, who died eight years ago.

title: War in Ukraine: On the front line, enemy artillery units come face to face
summary: For more than a year, the same Ukrainian and Russian artillery units have been battling it out on either side of the front – an exhausting duel in which the Russians are gaining the upper hand.

title: Residents evacuated after North Korea fires artillery shells near South Korean islands
summary: The act was the most serious escalation of tension between the two countries in decades. Seoul responded with live-fire drills of its own.

title: Iran hold funerals for victims of two IS-claimed bombings
summary: Iranian mourners, soldiers and officials gathered in the city of Kerman to lay to rest the 89 victims of two bombings committed at a state funeral – the most deadly attack in Iran since 1979 – the responsibility for which has been claimed by the Islamic State group.

title: Michelin-starred chef Mory Sacko: 'My parents dreamed of a better life for their children'
summary: The 31-year-old French chef of Malian origin reflects on his rigorous upbringing, the sense of hard work his parents instilled in him and finding success at a young age.

title: Sub-Saharan migrants in Tunisia under threat from kidnapping networks
summary: A new form of human trafficking is on the rise in the North African country, as sub-Saharan Africans are kidnapped by other migrants seeking ransom from relatives.

title: West Bank's most prestigious university once again navigates teaching during wartime
summary: Birzeit University, which has switched to virtual classes, has been the target of two Israeli army raids in three months, with students and teachers arrested and others targeted by settlers.

title: Azerbaijan names ex-oil executive to COP29 presidency
summary: Mukhtar Babayev, Azerbaijan's minister for ecology and natural resources and formerly a state oil company SOCAR executive, has been named president-delegate of the future COP29 – the second petrochemical executive in a row to hold the position.

title: Nadal knocked out of comeback tournament in quarter-finals
summary: The Spanish Grand Slam champion was beaten by Australian Jordan Thompson, who secured a semi-final against Grigor Dimitrov.

title: Carrefour drops PepsiCo products in stand against price hikes
summary: French supermarket chain Carrefour will no longer stock Lipton tea, 7Up, Doritos or Pepsi, saying that the company's price increases are 'unacceptable.'
